The R package `cder` provides a simple interface to the CDEC JSON 
Webservice. Getting CDEC data with `cder` is easy, just pass a 
station code to `query_cdec`:


```r
library(cder)
# get data for CDEC station NSL 
query_cdec("NSL")
#> # A tibble: 578 x 9
#>    StationID Duration SensorNumber SensorType DateTime           
#>    <chr>     <chr>           <int> <chr>      <dttm>             
#>  1 NSL       E                   1 RIV STG    2019-03-13 19:30:00
#>  2 NSL       E                   1 RIV STG    2019-03-13 19:45:00
#>  3 NSL       E                   1 RIV STG    2019-03-13 20:00:00
#>  4 NSL       E                   1 RIV STG    2019-03-13 20:15:00
#>  5 NSL       E                   1 RIV STG    2019-03-13 20:30:00
#>  6 NSL       E                   1 RIV STG    2019-03-13 20:45:00
#>  7 NSL       E                   1 RIV STG    2019-03-13 21:00:00
#>  8 NSL       E                   1 RIV STG    2019-03-13 21:15:00
#>  9 NSL       E                   1 RIV STG    2019-03-13 21:30:00
#> 10 NSL       E                   1 RIV STG    2019-03-13 21:45:00
#> # ... with 568 more rows, and 4 more variables: ObsDate <dttm>,
#> #   Value <dbl>, DataFlag <chr>, SensorUnits <chr>
```

The CDEC web service uses some default values for the duration code,
sensor number, and start/end dates. You can also specify these in 
the call to `query_cdec`:


```r
station = "NSL"
duration = "event"
sensor = 100 # electrical conductivity
start.date = Sys.Date() - 14
end.date = Sys.Date()

query_cdec(station, sensor, duration, start.date, end.date)
#> # A tibble: 1,339 x 9
#>    StationID Duration SensorNumber SensorType DateTime           
#>    <chr>     <chr>           <int> <chr>      <dttm>             
#>  1 NSL       E                 100 EL COND    2019-02-28 00:00:00
#>  2 NSL       E                 100 EL COND    2019-02-28 00:15:00
#>  3 NSL       E                 100 EL COND    2019-02-28 00:30:00
#>  4 NSL       E                 100 EL COND    2019-02-28 00:45:00
#>  5 NSL       E                 100 EL COND    2019-02-28 01:00:00
#>  6 NSL       E                 100 EL COND    2019-02-28 01:15:00
#>  7 NSL       E                 100 EL COND    2019-02-28 01:30:00
#>  8 NSL       E                 100 EL COND    2019-02-28 01:45:00
#>  9 NSL       E                 100 EL COND    2019-02-28 02:00:00
#> 10 NSL       E                 100 EL COND    2019-02-28 02:15:00
#> # ... with 1,329 more rows, and 4 more variables: ObsDate <dttm>,
#> #   Value <dbl>, DataFlag <chr>, SensorUnits <chr>
```

The web service supports multiple stations, sensors, and even 
duration codes:


```r
# get data for CDEC stations NSL and HUN
stations = c("NSL", "HUN")
# get electrical conductivity and stage
sensors = c(100, 1)
# get event data and hourly averages (where available)
durations = c("event", "hourly")

query_cdec(stations, sensors, durations)
#> # A tibble: 240 x 9
#>    StationID Duration SensorNumber SensorType DateTime           
#>    <chr>     <chr>           <int> <chr>      <dttm>             
#>  1 HUN       E                   1 RIV STG    2019-03-13 19:30:00
#>  2 HUN       E                   1 RIV STG    2019-03-13 19:45:00
#>  3 HUN       E                   1 RIV STG    2019-03-13 20:00:00
#>  4 HUN       E                   1 RIV STG    2019-03-13 20:15:00
#>  5 HUN       E                   1 RIV STG    2019-03-13 20:30:00
#>  6 HUN       E                   1 RIV STG    2019-03-13 20:45:00
#>  7 HUN       E                   1 RIV STG    2019-03-13 21:00:00
#>  8 HUN       E                   1 RIV STG    2019-03-13 21:15:00
#>  9 HUN       E                   1 RIV STG    2019-03-13 21:30:00
#> 10 HUN       E                   1 RIV STG    2019-03-13 21:45:00
#> # ... with 230 more rows, and 4 more variables: ObsDate <dttm>,
#> #   Value <dbl>, DataFlag <chr>, SensorUnits <chr>
```

That's it!
